intro: Brassica campestris var. quadrivalvis, commonly known as the four-angled mustard, is a variant of the mustard plant characterized by its quadrilateral stem. It is an annual herb native to temperate regions and is part of the Brassicaceae family. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, with alternate, pinnately lobed leaves. Its flowers are small, yellow, and arranged in racemes, while the fruit is a slender, four-angled silique containing several seeds. This variety is valued for its ornamental appeal and has been used in traditional medicine and as a source of oil.
